@JohnMar17136360 Great memories John. I used to go fishing near the Pyewipe pub with my dad in the 70’s, two hobbies rolled into one there, the Lincoln line opposite and a well stocked Fosdyke navigation. I used to hear 31/37’s on that avoiding line - heard but never seen as it was too far away.
@JohnMar17136360 That must have been an experience to remember John. Apparently the signalman at Pyewipe Jnc was nicknamed ‘Rusty’ on account of the colour of his hair!

@shuggeemonsta Apparently it’s to prevent the point detection being affected by the rails shifting too much as they expand rather than catastrophic buckling which can only be prevented with expansion joints anyway and this is unlikely to occur at the temperatures we experience in U.K.
@WilsonBone I know 🙄
@WilsonBone Apparently it’s to help prevent the point detection being affected by the rails shifting too much as they expand rather than rail buckling I get that but ITV news reported otherwise 🙄
@qmodeller That’s plausible 👍🏻
@RichardClem Remember it well 😂
@WilsonBone Good innit 😎
@johnwaddo Interesting as it goes against all basic metallurgical theory.

@Mark_Calvert Or is it that ambient temperature not great enough to buckle modern steel rail? Composition and quality of steel will also have an effect whereas steel grades used many years ago were more susceptible to creep at higher ambient temperature.
@eobhann @gjdash Oh right ok that makes sense

@gjdash It’s probably a placebo effect paint won’t prevent heat build up in steel and it’s effect on grain structure which by the way would need temperatures greater than 32 degrees to have any tangible effect in terms of buckling. Expansion joints do work however.
Apparently Network Rail painting certain sections of rail white to prevent buckling in the coming heat wave. As a qualified metallurgist I believe it won’t have much effect 😅
